Compute Univariate Log-Likelihood for GLM or Cox Model

Source: R/Rinternal.R
univariate_loglik.Rd

Calculates the log-likelihood of a single covariate effect under either a generalized linear model (GLM) family or a Cox proportional hazards model.

Arguments

x

Numeric vector of length n: covariate values.

y

For GLMs: numeric vector of length n; for Cox: numeric matrix with two columns (time, status) and n rows.

family

A GLM family object (e.g. gaussian(), binomial(), poisson()) or a Cox family list with element family="cox".

theta

Numeric scalar: coefficient at which to evaluate the log-likelihood.

offset

Numeric scalar or vector of length n: offset in the linear predictor.

ties

Character string: tie-handling method for Cox partial likelihood; one of "efron" or "breslow".

Value

A numeric scalar giving the log-likelihood of the univariate fit.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Gaussian example
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- 2 * x + rnorm(100)
univariate_loglik(x, y, family = gaussian(), theta = 2, offset = 0)

# Binomial example
x <- rnorm(200)
eta <- -1 + 1.5 * x
p <- plogis(eta)
y <- rbinom(200, 1, p)
univariate_loglik(x, y, family = binomial(link = "logit"),
                  theta = 1.5, offset = 0)

# Cox example
x <- rnorm(50)
times <- rexp(50)
status <- rbinom(50, 1, 0.5)
ymat <- cbind(times, status)
univariate_loglik(x, ymat, family = list(family = "cox"),
                  theta = 0.5, offset = 0, ties = "efron")
} # }
